title: Geoff Cooke (cyclist)
text:
Geoff Cooke (born 26 July 1944) is a British cycling coach. He was a <a href="British%20Cycling%23The%20British%20Cycling%20Federation">BCF</a> National Cycling Coach from 1979 to 1989, a <a href="British%20Cycling">BC</a> National Youth Sprint Coach from 2003 to 2009.
Biography.
Cooke was born in <a href="Crumpsall">Crumpsall</a>, <a href="Manchester">Manchester</a>. He competed in the <a href="Cycling%20at%20the%201972%20Summer%20Olympics%20%E2%80%93%20Men%27s%20sprint">Sprint</a> and <a href="Cycling%20at%20the%201972%20Summer%20Olympics%20%E2%80%93%20Men%27s%20tandem">Tandem Sprint</a> events at the 1972 Olympic Games in <a href="Munich">Munich</a>. Cooke represented England at the <a href="1974%20Commonwealth%20Games">1974 Commonwealth Games</a> in <a href="Christchurch">Christchurch</a>, where he won the Gold medal in the tandem sprint event. Along with winning the Commonwealth Championship he has won World Masters titles 46 times including winning the sprint championship for seven consecutive years between 1996 and 2002, and 64 times national champion.
Cooke broke the European record in the 500m TT for riders aged 60–64, whilst on the way to winning the gold medal at the 2008 European Masters Track Cycling Championships, with a new time of 37.244 seconds. Cooke retained his title in 2009, albeit in the 65–69 age category, he also won the sprint and later on the same year took gold in the sprint and 500m TT and silver in the scratch race at the World Masters Track Championships in <a href="Sydney">Sydney</a>.
He held the post of <a href="British%20Cycling">British Cycling</a>'s national cycling coach for 10 years, 1979-1989.
Between 2006 and 2009, Cooke took part in the reality TV show "<a href="The%20Games%20%28UK%20TV%20series%29">The Games</a>" as a cycling coach to the participating celebrities.
Cooke was also involved in coaching cycling for <a href="Drug%20Abuse%20Resistance%20Education">DARE UK</a>.
